The day before Ychoalay lest us, his chief emissary Hapaleolin intercepted Kepakainkin‚ a tribesman and brother-in-law of Oaherkaikin. As his wife was a Nakaike- tergehe‚ whilst his brothers dwelt amongst the Riikahes, he sometimes joined one tribe, some- times the other, and, on this very account, in- curred the hatred of both. Fearing the arri- val of Ychoalay, he withdrew from Oaherkaikin’s horde, which was shortly to be attacked, under pretext of watching the motions of the enemy3 but in reality with a treacherous design, which he put in execution, of meeting with the Riika- he'S‚ and conducting them to the horde of Oa- herkaikin: however, he was only a spectator of the fight, and afterwards deserted Oaherkaikin's town, and betook himself to that of St. Jero- nymo.

The horde of Oaherkaikin was a few leagues distant from the town of St. Ferdffland, nor did it.contain more than twenty men able to bear arms, the rest being at that time employed in harassing the colonies of the Spaniards But the small number of those who resisted were de— fended against all assaults by the natural situ- ation of the place.
